contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox writer |name = Darryl Ponicsan |image = Darryl Ponicsan 03A.jpg |caption = Darryl Ponicsan (2008) |birth_date = May 26, 1938 |birth_place = [[Shenandoah, Pennsylvania]] |pseudonym = [[Anne Argula]]<ref name=PBRef>{{cite web | url = http://www.pleasureboatstudio.com/Argula_HomicideMyOwn.htm | title = Homicide My Own | publisher = Pleasure Boat Studios | archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070623111637/www.pleasureboatstudio.com/Argula_HomicideMyOwn.htm | archivedate = 2007-06-23 }}</ref> }} '''Darryl Ponicsan''' (pronounced ''PAHN''-''i''-''son''; born May 26, 1938) is an [[United States|American]] writer. He is best known as the author of the 1971 [[novel]] ''[[The Last Detail]],'' which was adapted into a 1973 movie starring [[Jack Nicholson]]; and for the 1973 novel and [[screenplay]] ''[[Cinderella Liberty]],'' starring [[James Caan (actor)|James Caan]]. Ponicsan writes mystery novels under the pen name [[Anne Argula]]. ==Life and career== Ponicsan was born in [[Shenandoah, Pennsylvania|Shenandoah]], [[Pennsylvania]], the son of Anne (née Kuleck) and Frank G. Ponicsan, a merchant.<ref>http://www.filmreference.com/film/80/Darryl-Ponicsan.html</ref> He attended [[Muhlenberg College]], ([[Bachelor of Arts|A.B.]], 1959) and [[Cornell University]], ([[Master of Arts (postgraduate)|M.A.]], 1965). He was teacher of English at a high school in [[Owego (town), New York|Owego]], [[New York]], 1959–62; a social worker for [[Los Angeles County]], [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] in 1965, and teacher of high-school English in [[La Cañada Flintridge, California | La Cañada, California]] from 1966 to 1969. Ponicsan also wrote the screenplays for the [[CBS]] movie ''A Girl Called Hatter Fox'' (1977), the movies ''[[Taps (film)|Taps]]'' (1981), ''[[Vision Quest]]'' (1985), ''[[Nuts (film)|Nuts]]'' (1987), ''[[The Boost]]'' (1988), ''[[School Ties]]'' (1992), the HBO movie ''The Enemy Within'' (1992), and the CBS series ''The Mississippi'' (1983). ==Bibliography== * ''[[The Last Detail]]'' (New York: Dial Press, 1970) * ''Goldengrove'' (New York: Dial Press, 1971) * ''Andoshen, Pa.'' (New York: Dial Press, 1973) * ''[[Cinderella Liberty]]'' (New York: Harper and Row, 1973) * ''Tom Mix Died for Your Sins'' (New York: Delacorte Press 1975) * ''The Accomplice'' (New York: Harper and Row, 1975) * ''The Ringmaster'' (New York: Delacorte Press, 1978) * ''An Unmarried Man'' (New York: Delacorte Press 1980) * ''Last Flag Flying'' (The Wright Press, 2005) (sequel to ''The Last Detail'') * ''Homicide My Own'' (as [[Anne Argula]]) (New York: Pleasure Boat Studio, 2005)<ref name=PBRef/> * ''Walla Walla Suite: A Room with No View'' (as [[Anne Argula]]) (New York: Ballantine, 2007) * '' Krapp's Last Cassette'' (as [[Anne Argula]]) (Ballantine, 2009) [cf.
